page.title: 13LANDSCAPE
page.content: The landscape is pleasant with gentle slopes, tiny streams and wide skies. Intensely farmed, it is rather too neat and bare in places, hedges having been destroyed to allow for the use of ever larger farm machinery. To offset this there is a large shaggy very wet area of unimproved grassland in the northwest corner and an old osier bed has grown into a miniature wilderness between Cratfield and Silverleys Green. On one farm the planting of trees in hedgerows and in odd corners has greatly improved the view to the northeast from Cratfield. Trees have been planted along some road verges recently, but they are as yet too small to affect the landscape. An increase in winter crops has made the prospect in winter much greener than it was and the acid yellow fields of rape brighten the spring.
